title: Blog/Notes
text: I will be publishing a series of notes and observations, primarily concerning hydrology and meteorology, with secondary attention to earth sciences. Occasional personal essays will also be included.

title: About
text: PengXuan Zhu’s homepage

title: Pengxuan Zhu
text:
gmail
  
  
    
     arlionn
  
  
    
     ResearchGate
  

  
  
I am currently studying at Nanjing University of Information Science and Technology, with a strong research interest in extreme hydrological events, global climate change, and eco-hydrology. In my work, I utilize hydrological models such as the Soil and Water Assessment Tool (SWAT) and PCR-GLOBWB to investigate and address complex research questions in these fields.
As a student exploring the path of scientific research, my dream is to contribute meaningfully to a world facing dynamic and multifaceted changes.
I enjoy contemplating my life and research while on long-distance rides.



2021-: Bachelor , Nanjing University of Information Science and Technology, China, majoring in Hydrology and Water Resources.

title: Publications
text:
Awards

2023-2024: President, Science and Technology Association, School of Hydrology and Water Resources, Nanjing University of Information Science and Technology
2022: Third Prize, 3rd China National Numerical Modeling Competition for Water Sciences (Organized by Chinese Hydraulic Engineering Society)
2021-2022: Permanent Representative, Student Congress, Nanjing University of Information Science and Technology

title: Skills
text:
Python: Proficient in data processing, scientific computing, and scientific plotting within the hydrology and meteorology domains. Experienced in using the Flask lightweight web framework and interfacing with high-performance Fortran computational routines.
Fortran: Learned for developing and applying hydrologic and meteorological models (e.g., SWAT), atmospheric dynamics, and hydraulic simulations. Utilized for writing efficient and dedicated numerical computations.
Linux System: Experienced user.
